Comments_List: All of Ugaritic grammar and some basic vocab.
We gained an introductory knowledge about Ugaritic grammar and syntax, beginning with the alphabet and encompassing the whole grammar.

The ability to transcribe and translate cuneiform, which was a completely new skill. I also learned more about the syntax of Semitic languages in general, especially as it relates to the stems of verbs.
Ancient Northwest Semitic history, culture, and language. Also collaboration in translation assignments.
How to read, transcribe and translate Ugaritic cuneiform.

Before this course I did not know what Ugaritic was, and now I can translate cuneiform (with the help of notes and vocab and such). I learned a whole language in a semester, and I'm excited to get better.
Vocab and Garmmar Quizzes would be nice.

This was a really interesting course, and I think the setup was perfect. The smaller class size was I think integral for how this worked so well - I can't imagine it would have been so engaging with 20 or more students. I can't think of any ways it could be improved.
I was very pleased with the course. There was a lot more information to absorb in the latter half of the semester compared to the first half, but I assume that is natural for any language.

This course is a pretty intense language, and could be more useful to learn in smaller sections over more class sessions. Sometimes it was a lot of material to digest at once. Also, more equal homework assignments would spread out the workload and help build on skills in a more structured fashion. It was great to have a take home final though because this language is like solving a puzzle, and it aids learning rather than memorization to have more time with material and do it carefully and thoughtfully.
Yes, to others in my program. It is an important skill for aspiring OT scholars.
Absolutely! It's very in the weeds, but if a peer of mine was interested in starting Semitic studies beyond Hebrew, this seems to be the place to begin!
Yes. It is a very necessary course for students of the Hebrew Bible like myself, so I would recommend it to anyone in my concentration.
Yes because the language is important to my discipline and Jimmy is a fantastic instructor.
If you are pursuing study in Hebrew Bible, then yes.
Yes! Ugaritic is a cool language. Jimmy is fantastic at what she does.
